captions.text: M:Mayan Flower asks S:How does Korea view teenage pregnancy? Are any teenage moms and dads in Korea that you’ve seen?
In North America and central America (I’m Guatemalan) there tend to be a lot of teenage parents
M:Hm… S:Hm… M:This is a pretty awkward topic
Probably because we’re not South Korean teenage girls… M:Yeah… S:Though…
Also we didn’t grow up in South Korea. We’ve really only have been here for about five years
So in those five years we haven’t actually seen any teenage pregnancy and the reason why might be because according to Wikipedia statistics.
Because Wikipedia is so reliable. Amongst developed countries US has the highest teenage pregnancy rate and South Korea has the lowest.
I think it’s like two pregnancies in like a thousand.
M:South Korea and Japan are down there, right? S: yeah, South Korea and Japan are really low there
And this kind of goes hand in hand with our experience because I was a high school teacher at an all-girls high school for three years
And in those three years I did not witness any teenage pregnancy nor heard any rumors of these things happening
In my middle school I didn’t see any pregnancy either. BUT back when we were high school teachers and high school students in Canada
We did notice a whole lot of teenage pregnancy
I think you might have noticed that more than me because I think that I only knew one girl in all of my high school career
That was pregnant S:really? M:Yeah S: I taught one class in which three girls were pregnant.
M:Really? S:One class. M:And when you were a high school student? S: Lots of girls were pregnant M:really!?
M:Perhaps it depends on the area where you grow up in S:Pickering represent~
Ok, so we can’t tell you exactly why teenage pregnancy is so low here.
That’s not really to answer because I’m sure that there are a whole lot of factors that play into there being very low pregnancy rates here in Korea
The number one factor being that teenagers in the west have been poisoned by the devil and God has turned his back on them
And now as a result he has bestowed his grace upon South Korea and is not letting to get pregnant a lot of teenagers
But seriously… As to why there might be a low pregnancy rate in Korea, but this is just our kind of educated discussing guess
There are a whole bunch of factors and we just gonna talk about a couple that we might think are relevant
I think the first and easiest factor is that Korean teens don’t really have the time to date or have sex
I don’t even think that Korean teenagers have time to eat anything.
They go to school from like 7AM to like midnight a lot of the time.
Where do you have time in there to make a boom boom jiggity jiggity?
Where do you have time to have a boyfriend or girlfriend? You don’t even have time for part-time jobs, so I feel like
If you’re constantly in school going one school, to a study school after program and then you’re getting on a bus and going straight home
When do you have time for anything?
Back when I was a high school student I was finishing school at 3PM and I had the rest of the day totally to myself
And also a lot of things that I could do there like… Play chess.
M:Chess is a good one S:Yep M:we could join after-school clubs that were not at all unsavory.
S:Or join an orgy.  M: Ok, well. I hope that didn’t happen. S:Pickering represent M:Alright…
And even when people are in school for that long you might thing “well I’m sure they can sneak out and do things..”
But honestly, the teachers keep a really close watch on them  S:Oh yes
They will call the parents and report if the girls are putting on make-up in the washroom. So for example.. S:No joke
“Your girl is putting make-up on. I think she’s planning on skipping her after school study class and meeting up with a boy”
The hagwon teachers will check to see who’s checking in and if they’re late or not…
So there is kind of a community… S:Big brother is watching you M:Yes.
The second thing that we think is important Is that even if you find time somehow to make boom boom jiggidy jiggidy
You can’t find a place to do so.
So in North America you tend to have houses and you have like a lot of space. Like you might be able to hang out in the back yard
Or like have a pool party or people have house parties.
I had an entire basement to myself when I was in high school for example. So I had that level of privacy.
But when it comes to like apartments in South Korea, because a lot of people do live in apartments,
It’s not really like you have that much privacy in there.
And there aren’t really house properties with like fenced off properties S:barely, unless you’re ballin
M: exactly unless you’re BALLING.
Yeah so most people really do live in apartments or they live in smaller houses where you can hear your neighbors and everyone’s around.
And you might even be living in a house with your grandmother and grandparents. It’s very family oriented, so…
The point is that if you can find a way to sneak in your boyfriend or girlfriend then… then what are you gonna do?
Where you gonna go? Like your family is there. There is no privacy like… you not gonna put on a performance… unless that’s your thing
But I really doubt that as a high school student you really wanna be doing this in front of your family
So where are you going to do it? In a 24-hour coffee shop? I don’t think so.
Well there are some places. There are like love motels that you can go to and there are DVD rooms
In which people don’t actually watch DVDs… M: We do.
Well now that we found out what people do and with all the juices that might be going around and
M: Argh…  S: I don’t actually go to DVD rooms anymore but the whole point is that M: I thought that stickiness was from coke! *sobs*
S: The whole point M:I thought it was minty chocolate *sobs* S:It’s… It’s possible. You can find room
It’s just that it’s not that easy. You don’t have as much privacy in South Korea as you do like in North America.
So basically two factors: #1 you have no time, #2 you have no space to actually do it as a teenager in Korea
As a result it’s kind of difficult to get pregnant if you don’t have any place to actually do it.
Now this last point: I don’t really think it has completely to do with teenage pregnancy, but it’s something that’s really socially different than what we’ve experienced in North America
S: Right. M: Sex education isn’t really a thing here. You know that awkward class in like high school where like the boys and girls are separated
The poor gym teachers drawing a picture of like a womb that looks like a sproose moose
S:Dodge Ram M:The w…what? The Dodge Ram? S:If you looked at the Dodge Ram logo it looks like the… M:the ovaries and stuff S:Ovaries yeah
M:the brovaries S:Never look at Dodge Ram the same way again
So like they don’t have that awkward sex ed class where they talk about different forms of contraception or like how to be safe
Or talk about STDs. While we were in the university in North America, they had a lot of stuff about like sex education
Like posters about going to get tested or if you’re dating someone that you guys should get tested or like different contraception
Or like birth control. Well they are always telling people like “Be careful”
While in like South Korean Universities from the people that we’ve spoken with, they haven’t actually seen any of that stuff on campus
So the whole point of this is that we’re not necessarily sure if there is low visibility when it comes to sex ed because there is low frequency of it
Or because Korea is very conservative and that’s why it’s so very taboo to talk about but we think it’s kind of relevant to talk about at least
M: Yeah. I feel like it’s a combo of both of them. Because even if you look at Korean media like movies or Korean dramas or even in kpop
You don’t really see a huge amount of sexuality happening like you see how they kiss S:I’d like to see the Korean version of Game of Thrones
M: Oh my God, can you imagine? Whoa~ S:That ain’t making on air M:there’s no HBO Equivalent in that work in Korea S: No…
Now all these factors combined isn’t to say that South Korea doesn’t experience any teenage pregnancy. It does
We just haven’t actually seen it ourselves
But when teenage pregnancy does happen in Korea, Suzy told us that there was a documentary on teenage pregnancy in Korea
And the issues they go through but we’re gonna talk about that on our blog post.
So make sure you check that out.
So that’s it for this week’s TL;DR if you have a question that we might have more experience with for next  TL;DR
Leave your question in the comment section below.
Or check out the questions that are already asked and you can thumb them up to draw them to our attention.
And don’t forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs, where we talk about things that we barely know anything about
M: You said suscribe S:Coz I say it quickly. Suscribe. Sesuality~ M: Oh, Junsu S: diudiungdiungdiungdiungdiung diung~

comments.text:
I think you just missed a HUGE point in this video. Pregnancy, or sex for 
that matter is "supposed" to be between a married couple. The first night 
of marriage is supposed to be the first time you have sex. Unlike the 
United States traditional Korean families put a lot of emphasis on this 
point even cultural media adheres to this value. The wikipedia reported 
values are obviously off for two reasons first, most abortions are illegal 
in Korea it is VERY difficult to get one and second, families wouldn't want 
to report that their teenage daughter is pregnant it would be a disgrace to 
the family name. Your father would probably disown you..﻿

comments.text:
Even with the amount of abortion unaccounted for in Asian countries, the 
number of teenage pregnancy is still incredibly low. It's interesting, 
because they really don't discuss sex-ed in school or in their homes. 
America, on the other hand, discusses it a shit ton and still has a bunch 
of teenage pregnancies. And it's mostly certain races that fill up those 
statistics. This tells me it has more to do with culture than anything 
else.﻿
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text:
+123itstime4tea From what I learned, through general research when I was in 
college, lack of proper sex education is what statistically leads to teen 
pregnancy, STDs, etc. Going with that notion and what they discussed in the 
video, South Korea should have high rates of pregnant teens...which it 
definitely doesn't. So I agree, it can't be sex education or a lack 
thereof. If you ask me, I think it has more to do with culture and family. 
The whole "shame" thing and possibility of being ostracized by peers and 
disowned by parents--all probably act as a deterrent for most Korean youth.

Just coming from experience here-we didn't have sex ed in private school 
which left it still even awkward to bring up in middle school, so no one 
dated or made dirty jokes. The minute I went to Public School from Private,

comments.text:
I'll be remembering from now on not to read the comments on this channel's 
videos over there being more racists commenting than anything else... 
People here are heavily jumping to a love of abortion, and false claims of 
East Asian countries being mostly Christian when there is no such East 
Asian country on Earth as one full of abortions, and Christians.
(The dominant religions in Asia are Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, and 
Protestantism (as opposed to any other Christian sect). They need to stop 
listening to lying preachers telling them made up statistics, or made up 
averages about the Christian frequency in these countries.)
(And, Korea's abortion laws are tighter than in most Northern hemisphere 
countries, and almost all other Asian nations. So, the people saying the 
statistics can't be known, and that sources claiming high rates are lying 
are probably the ones telling the truth.)﻿

comments.text:
I think a better question would be why teen pregnancy is so high in the US. 
Living in Europe, I have heard of maybe one teenage pregnancy, at the third 
remove, and the teenagers in question were just about ready for college 
anyway. We do have a few sex ed classes, condoms are being distrubuted 
freely at youth events and the pill encouraged to women and girls. 
Shouldn't be that different from the US, so what gives? ﻿

comments.text:

with a normal education or even higher education, who don't really know 
anything about birth control. It's a lot more conservative

comments.text:
I think the difference is that there are still a lot of conservative areas 
in the US. There are places where high school students either receive no 
sex education, or they are only told not to have sex because they'll get 
pregnant and catch STDs. So when these teenagers have sex they are less 
likely to use protection.

comments.text:
I have to slightly disagree about it not happening that often. Because of 
their culture they are probably less likely than teens in other parts of 
the world. I think that it happens, but because of the stigma and the fact 
that becoming pregnant before you are married is so taboo and looked down 
upon, I think that their parents are more likely to have the situation 
"taken care of" before anyone finds out about it. Or, they have the babies 
in secret and give them up. I watched a very interesting documentary called 
"Baby Box". It's about a minister who runs an orphanage where he built a 
box similar to a mailbox, where people can anonymously leave their unwanted 
babies. ﻿

comments.author: thatsmeja Lammy

comments.text:
I was told by my friend a few years ago that there actually may be a lot of 
pregnancies due to the fact that many Koreans don't like to have sex with 
protection. There is no sexual education classes in Korea so people find 
out the hard way by just trying. Many of my guy friends have admitted to 
not having sex with a condom and always say "I pull out" as if it was the 
answer to not getting a girl pregnant, which anyone who has lived in 
America or Canada would know that is not the case. But continuing with what 
I was saying earlier, my friend told me that she believes that if there are 
women who do get pregnant in her teens or hell even in her early twenties 
while in College they normally "take care" of the problem. And to that I 
feel like possibly there aren't many activist who are pro-life here. Which 
raises another question as to how comfortable are people here with 
abortion. In Korean society women are to go to high school, get into a nice 
college, finish college, land a great job, and then settle before she's 30 
which is the age of (Why the fuck aren't you married yet) here. It all goes 
hand and hand with the culture.﻿
comments.author: mikeyjaynes92

comments.text:
I am korean and I did get a sex-ed when I was in 6th grade and both male 
and female students are in the class room. Talking about sex between 
parents and children doesnt really happen because most families are still 
conservative but that is different from families to families. I think it is 
starting to do that kind of sex-ed now on. Abortion does happen in the 
clinic... Korean teenage dating used to be not really encouraged because 
people think teenage is time to study since dating and love stuff can be 
done later on in the life. However, recently, teenage dating got popular 
with more Americanized but still not really popular. Also many middle 
school and high school in korea is usually either only-girl school or 
only-boy school which separate them each other. That is why college 
freshmen in korea have a "dreamy vision" or almost like a myth that you 
will have a boyfriend/girlfriend immediately when you go to college... ﻿

Oh the Irony.﻿

comments.text:
Disregarding social stigma and general ignorance about sex, it's actually

comments.text:
If you look at North America, sex ed leads to lower teenage pregnancy 
rates. That doesn't mean that lack of sex ed makes them have more sex. It 
just means that when they do have sex, they don't do it safely because they 
were never taught this in sex ed. You guys think that the lack of sex ed in 
Korea leads to them having less sex as teenagers, but this is not true. 
It's not even a factor in the frequency of having sex. It's a factor in the 
amount of teenage pregnancies, so the percentage of sex encounters that 
result in teenage pregnancy. The factors for Korea's low teenage pregnancy 
rates are, what you guys mentioned, lack of space and time.﻿

comments.text:
I live in the United States and I'm a Junior in high school (16) and I've 
known of at least 25-30 teenage pregnancies in my town in the past 3 years. 
Some girls have had as many as 3 babies before they're 18. And I live in a 
pretty small town, the population is only about 17,000. I'm sure there have 
been many other teenage pregnancies that I just haven't heard about or paid 
any attention to. It's almost like it's not even a rare thing anymore, some 
girls try to get pregnant while they're teenagers. Which I don't think is 
very smart, not because they wouldn't be loving parents, but I feel like 
it's important to have a good education and job to support the kids that 
you have. It's better for the mom and the child. Plus, I just don't think 
that teenagers are emotionally ready to have children of their own. One of 
my teachers always said the brain isn't fully developed until 25, so it's 
difficult to make life-altering decisions when you're still a kid. So she 
always told us not to get married or pregnant before we're at least 25.
Not all girls in America are slutty, lol. My goal is actually to NOT get 
pregnant, I want to adopt and have foster children when I'm older. Ideally, 
after I graduate college and have spent a few years in my career.﻿

comments.text:
I don't know about Australia specifically, but here in the U.S. high school 
is considered a bit late for sex-ed classes. Generally a sex-ed class would 
be offered in years 7 and/or 8, around age 11-13, so that the new info can 
coincide with the onset of puberty. Some high schools choose to mandate 
student health classes, many of which include some sex-ed refresher info, 
but many high schools just ignore the topic entirely (until one student 
impregnates another student, and suddenly all the adults are confused and 
horrified).

comments.text:
I heard about Sanbon students being forced to have abortions (and being 
caught in the bathrooms having sex) from the Korean teachers at my school. 
Most of the ESL teachers are kept in the dark about these things because 
they don't want to give a bad impression about Korea. But it does happen. 
If the girl wants to give it up for adoption, she'll have to "stay with her 
grandma" for a few months in some rural town. Also, all the best gossip is 
in Korean. ﻿

+deadbutmoving No, it's true. there are over 400,000 abortions there a

decided against it.

comments.text:
True. I had a friend who studied in Japan, and she was shocked at how 
normal it was for girls to have abortions. They would do it during lunch 
and be back at school again. It really wasn't anything special or a big 
deal. I don't remember where in Japan it was, but one of the larger cities.

comments.author: Ma5jay5dontxdoxthat

comments.text:
+Ma5jay5dontxdoxthat they have? that is really disgusting... but you should 
learn more about the one child policy before you talk about it... 
basically, yes it applies to everyone but there are exceptions for like 
endangered indigenous peoples, which can have more than one child and there 
is the case that a couple, where both of them come from an one-child family 
are allowed to have two children... and there is also the case that rich 
people can pay to be allowed to have more children...
also it was the wrong gender, though, it might be that that has changed... 
originally it was that many Chinese if they didn't got a boy they would 
hide the girl (see lost children) abandon them to shelters or worst case 
kill them... (boy's were worth much more than girls) but nowadys it can be 
that, because of this they ran low an females (to the point that they had 
to "import" wives) which made them more eager to get girls than boys
comments.author: LilysDream

comments.text:
Bullshit! You don't have the data to make that claim. Abortion is illegal 
in Korea and Japan. The Governments don't keep statistics about abortion.

China has a high abortion rates because it's not only legal, but often 
mandated by it's one child policy.
